abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Telecommunications
            Technical Assistance Project for Bangladesh were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: this project
            was relatively small from an investment perspective, but it
            was very opportunistic and focused as it was specifically
            designed to take advantage of the high-level political will
            to undertake telecom sector reforms, and to support the
            newly-established regulatory agency which needed significant
            strengthening. The initial delays and risks to project
            outcomes could be reasonably attributed to the lack of
            sufficient resources at the implementing agencies when the
            project started. Hence, the credit could have required the
            Government to allocate sufficient staff resources at the
            implementing agencies, and the project design should have
            provisioned for full-time and incentivized staff for
            implementation. Ministry of Post and Telecommunications
            (MOPT) also tried to address this issue during
            implementation by submitting an amended Technical Assistance
            Project Proforma (TAPP) for additional resources and having
            its staff trained under the project. The project seized the
            opportunity of high-level political will to restructure
            Bangladesh Telegraph and Telephone Board (BTTB), but
            encountered an unexpectedly high level of resistance from
            BTTB's management and labor unions. Hence, the use of
            methodological approaches such as political economy and/or
            stakeholder analysis could have provided more realistic
            contextual basis for future projects.
